curam.util.client.domain.convert

Class AbstractConverter

  • java.lang.Object
    • curam.util.common.plugin.AbstractPlugIn
      • curam.util.common.domain.AbstractDomainPlugIn
        • curam.util.client.domain.AbstractClientDomainPlugIn
          • curam.util.client.domain.convert.AbstractConverter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    curam.util.client.domain.convert.ClientDomainConverter, DomainConverter, DomainPlugIn, PlugIn
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DateTimeConverter, SvrBlobConverter, SvrBooleanConverter, SvrCharConverter, SvrDateConverter, SvrDoubleConverter, SvrFloatConverter, SvrInt16Converter, SvrInt32Converter, SvrInt64Converter, SvrInt8Converter, SvrMoneyConverter, SvrStringConverter

    public abstract class AbstractConverter
extends AbstractClientDomainPlugIn
implements curam.util.client.domain.convert.ClientDomainConverter
    An abstract class for converters that implements the basic plug-in interface methods. Custom converter plug-ins should never try to implement the DomainConverter interface directly; they should extend either this abstract class or an existing converter plug-in implementation.

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        Gets the name of the plug-in. This is usually the simple name used to identify the plug-in when loaded. Many different plug-in classes may share the same name if they implement the same type of behavior. For example, "converter" may be used as the name of a plug-in that performs data conversion operations, but there may be different "converter" classes implementing these operations.
        Specified by:
        getName in interface PlugIn
        Returns:
        The name "converter".

      • format

        public java.lang.String format(java.lang.Object data)
                        throws ConversionException
        Formats a value to a string. This default implementation identifies if the data is a number and, if it is, formats it as a number using Java's locale-specific number formatter; otherwise it calls the object's toString method. Override this as necessary.
        Specified by:
        format in interface DomainConverter
        Parameters:
        data - The data object to the formatted.
        Returns:
        The string representation of the data.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - If the formatting fails.
        See Also:
        DomainConverter.format(Object)

      • formatGeneric

        Throws:

      • parseGeneric

        public java.lang.Object parseGeneric(java.lang.String data)
                              throws ConversionException
        Parses a generic string representation of an object. The generic parser is assumed to be the same as the user-data parser, so it calls the DomainConverter.parse(String) method by default. However, due to the danger of side-effects on the generic parsing behavior if the DomainConverter.parse(String) is overridden, all of the core converter classes override this method to ensure that the parsing code is independent and that either parse method can be overridden without unwanted side-effects. The existence of this implementation, therefore, is for reasons of backward-compatibility, rather than to reduce the amount of implementation required. This method must always be overridden where the normal and generic parsing behavior is different, such as for dates and date-times.
        Specified by:
        parseGeneric in interface DomainConverter
        Parameters:
        data - The generic string representation to be parsed.
        Returns:
        The data value using the appropriate type.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - If the parsing fails.
        See Also:
        DomainConverter.parseGeneric(String)

      • validate

        public void validate(java.lang.Object data)
              throws ConversionException
        Validates a value. This implementation just throws a NullPointerException if the value is null; override this to implement any domain-specific validations.
        Specified by:
        validate in interface DomainConverter
        Parameters:
        data - The data object to be validated.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - If the validation fails.
        See Also:
        DomainConverter.validate(Object)

      • acceptData

        public boolean acceptData(java.lang.Object data)
                   throws PlugInException
        Indicates if the plug-in will accept the given data for processing. It is up to the plug-in to decide what data it will accept. This method is called by the system before any processing methods of the specific types of supported plug-ins are called. Those processing methods will not be called if the data is not accepted, so this method allows the other methods on this plug-in to be written with the minimum of safety checks.

        This implementation accepts all data without any checks.

        Overrides the basic implementation to reject any null data or data whose type is not assignable to the class returned by the DomainConverter.getDomainClass() method. A detailed exception will be throws in either case. The overridden method is still called after checking for null and checking the type.

        Specified by:
        acceptData in interface PlugIn
        Overrides:
        acceptData in class AbstractPlugIn
        Parameters:
        data - The data to be processed; may be null.
        Returns:
        true if the plug-in will accept the data for processing, false otherwise. If false, an error will be reported by the system.
        Throws:
        PlugInException - If the reason for the rejection of the data is complex and a more specific exception message would make it easier to determine how to remedy the problem, an exception may be thrown instead of returning false.

      • getGenericLocale

        public java.util.Locale getGenericLocale()
        Gets the locale that is used when parsing generic values. These include values embedded in XML data or values of domain options in the application model.
        Specified by:
        getGenericLocale in interface DomainConverter
        Returns:
        The generic locale.
        See Also:
        DomainConverter.getGenericLocale()
